Nestled in a ravine within the SLC limits, we followed our visit to the park with a who-cares-if-we-get-lost drive among the beautiful residential areas flanking the  east ridge of Memory Grove Park, where we encountered yet more incredible views of the SLC area.
If you want somewhere to go for a walk or run then this is your place, nice area with families and people walking dogs etc

Took my daughters dog . Leashed in the park.  Shade  water and then you start on the freedom Trail which is unleashed and your dogs can run around and play in the water. Fun for kids to lots of dogs lots of people. 
I parked across from the capital and walked down the switchbacks.

We walked to this park from the Hyatt House Hotel and it was way too far a hike in the hot sun. The park is beautiful with a creek flowing through it. It's a very lush and peaceful area. There are lots of elegant memorials /monuments around and about the park. There is a trail where dogs are allowed to hike on off leash but they must be on a leash in the other areas of the park although we saw lots of people not following the rule. I guess it's not enforced. Our dog had a blast on the trail. There were several families there having fun together and enjoying picnics. It was a pleasant place to spend time at.

I enjoy going through Memorial Park every time I go to salt Lake City! Sometimes I just look at the park, and sometimes I read the writing on the monuments. The visitors are nice, but some let dogs off-leash illegally.

name: Lake  Blanche Trail
reviews: A moderate hike of 2 hr up and 1 hr down from the car park, Blanche Lake is a gem. The hike gets bit steep towards the end. Being winter didn't find too many hikers. The lake was frozen. The sharp peak at the backdrop is rather dramatic. Awesome all round views. I definitely want to hike here in summer too. Do carry water and snacks. In winters, micro spikes is advisable.

I was visiting St Lake and found this trail.  This is a medium difficulty trail and you have to be somewhat physically fit to do this.  It is uphill the whole way.  Most of the trail is well groomed but there are some areas which are rocky.  The trail took me about 2.5 hours to complete.  I was walking at a brisk pace since I didn't start till late in the afternoon and wanted to be done before it got dark.  Suggestion is to start early in the day and plan for around 3-4 hours depending how long you plan to stay at the top.  

One of the best trails I have hiked.  You can hear the waterfall in the near distant majority of the way.  Lots of shady spots along the way and large rocks along the trail to take a break.  Once you get to the top (by the lake) the rocks are beautiful.  The lake is gorgeous and I wish I had more time to just enjoy the scenery and inhale the fresh air.  Definitely a must do if you in St Lake.

Get there early for parking in the small lot near the trailhead! It took us almost 3hrs to go up, with plenty of stops to take photos and rest (we are complete amateurs and had our 60yo mom with us). The trail is well marked and the view at the top (and also throughout) is worth the climb.

This is perhaps my favorite Big Cottonwood Canyon hike; I've done it multiple times and never tire of it.  It's especially spectacular in the fall when the leaves change color, since the gamble (scrub) oak and aspen are all yellow, the maples are bright red, and the conifers are green.  When all those colors are seen against the lake and blue sky, it's just breathtakingly beautiful.  The trail also features numerous places where you can see glacial scarring on the granite.  And if it's not too crowded and you hike quietly, there is plenty of wildlife to see as well.

Once you reach Lake Blanche, there are less travelled trails down to two smaller sister lakes--Lake Florence and Lake Lillian.  There are campsites by each lake.  But be aware that if you hike down to them the only way out is to hike back up to Lake Blanche before descending on the main trail, since there are no cut-offs from the main trail to the lower lakes.

The hike begins in a small parking area which fills up quickly; it's not unusual to have to park quite a ways up the road on the shoulder and walk back to the trailhead.  The lower part of the trail features a small waterfall and is popular with families and young children, but you quickly leave that crowd behind as the trail starts to climb, since it gets very steep.  You ascend about 2,700 feet for about 3.5 miles before reaching Lake Blanche and it's unrelentingly uphill, and often without shade in the afternoon, so take plenty of water and plan on frequent breaks to catch your breath if you're not in marathon-running shape. The whole hike (not counting extended tin at the top of spur hikes) usually takes me around 3 hours, but I stop often to enjoy the view so it can certainly be hiked more quickly. But unless you're a trail runner, I'd count on at least 2 1\2 hours.  Once at the top, you can see the entire valley open up below you as well as the gorgeous mountain scenery all around.  It's definitely a class-A mountain hike.  One of Utah's very best!

The hike to Lake Blanche is probably the favorite of all the hikes in BBC. It starts as an average incline with a few steeper spots for about 1 1/2 miles. The final 1/3 is steep with many switch-back for an additional 1 mile. You can go any day of the week and feel comfortable since the path is well used. In the final mile, there are 200 ft. of rockfall, but it isn't schist. The hike rises appx. 2300 ft. It should take appx 2 1/2 hrs at an average pace. Lots of people don't make it to the top but all seem to enjoy it.

name: Kindig It Design
reviews: If you are into cars you have to do this tour. The tours are on specific Fridays due to possible filming schedules. It easy to book a spot on line and the price is very modest ($5). We really loved that this was very personal up close experience of the amazing work and people at Kindig It Design. Brad was a great tour guide and led us on a full tour in and around over 20 projects in various phases of work. The tour took about an hour. Brad provided us with a lot of information that will enhance the enjoyment of watching Bitchin Rides!

My wife and I had a tour on Friday Aug 2nd, This is the coolest places to tour a working custom car shop. This shop was super clean very organized. We saw 4 cars in the front showroom just waiting to be picked up after getting work done. Then we toured the back shop work area with around 20 cars an early 60's corvette, Early custom Chevy pickup, Karmann Ghia, Caddy convertible, Gullwing Mercedes, Mustang ect... on and on to many to remember in the shop along with one of Dave's personal VW 4 dr Van with a flat bed. Kevdogg's slammed white Chevy Suburban waiting for Dave to figure out the custom wheel type. Cameras are off limits in the back shop work area for good reason, some very cool custom work going on here. We had a chance to meet Dave and Kevdogg for a photo op outside. They were strapping down a sand buggy behind a motorhome heading out for some weekend fun in the mountains after a week of the hard work on all the customers cars.  If I am ever back in Salt Lake City I will tour this place again, Kindig it Design is AWESOME!!!! Terry Anway from Michigan

As seen on TV Kindig-It- Design from the TV show on the "Velocity Channel", "B&*%N Rides". We made a trip into Salt Lake City from Yellowstone on our long cross Country trip this year to check out Kindig It. They have some really great customs on the show, and had to check them out. The week we were here, the crew was in Reno for the Good Guys Meet. So not very many cars to see. They are notorious for several builds and restorations, and just had to check it out. The 1968 Chevelle, "The Atomic SS", that they did was here, and the rest from the TV show were either with them in Reno, or hid inside the shop, which is off limits to the public. There is a show room that only had one car that was a stock looking Corvette. I did meet his daughter, Baylee, who runs the showroom was very nice and friendly, and allowed me a picture op with her, Thank you Baylee. There were several projects outside that we were allowed to look at, but were not allowed inside the shop. and I can understand that. When they return and get things set up in the new showroom area, it should be a better visit. If in the Salt Lake City Area, you may get lucky and see some of the awesome rides they build. I enjoyed it and there were only a couple cars to see, of which most were in various stages of builds. Worth a stop, especially if interested in Custom cars or appreciate killer rides. Trip advisor won't allow me to use the name of the show, but those that watch it know it.  B*&%n Rides.

We made a slight detour on our drive into the States to visit the site of one of our favourite TV shows.  Unfortunately we weren't there on a day of a tour --- next time.

We visited the small showroom and gift area.  The cars are even more beautiful in person.  

On the way out, we saw Kevin in the parking lot.  We asked him if he would take a picture with two fans.  He was very generous with his time and we chatted for a few minutes before letting him get back to work.

If you're a fan of the show, it's worth the stop.

If you are into cars you have to do this tour. The tours are on specific Fridays due to possible filming schedules. It easy to book a spot on line and the price is very modest ($5). We really loved that this was very personal up close experience of the amazing work and people at Kindig It Design. Brad was a great tour guide and led us on a full tour in and around over 20 projects in various phases of work. The tour took about an hour. Brad provided us with a lot of information that will enhance the enjoyment of watching Bitchin Rides!

Visited on a Tuesday afternoon... Nobody around except a very polite and helpful guy in the store.  Sat in the chairs with Dave's poster between us so we can at least lie and said we met Dave.  Yes, our friends are not that bright. 🤔. Few cars to see. T-shirts are not screen printed but plastic applied decals. 

They build a great car though!  So we bought shirts anyway.

My husband is a huge fan of the show and while we were in Salt Lake City on vacation, he just had to go.  What a great tour of a custom car garage.   Biggest disappointment was Dave and Kevdog were off filming and not there.  The showroom is small with just a couple of cars, a beautiful Corvette and a awesome Lincoln, a small gift shop with T-shirts, hats, etc and then the offices upstairs.  After a brief introduction from Dave's daughter who led the tour we were taken back to the working garage.  NO pictures can be taken from this point on.   We watched the mechanics/designers as they worked on various cars around the garage.   The tour takes about 40 minutes or so, cost is minimal and held to only 10 people (I think) and it's definitely worth the trip if you're a car fan.  Great place .
We were tuned away, they would not let us in because of filming.. nothing on their website to warn us ... we went out of our way on a trip from Houston  and they would not let us in........

name: Salt Palace Convention Center
reviews: HUGE Convention Centre!  Lots of room for vendors and visitors as well as many classrooms for workshops!  WOW!  Fabulous!
Attending a genealogy conference.  Large spacious facility. Excellent staff.  Many food vendors to choose from. Facility is well maintained

The Palace is huge! The staff was great plenty of food options for almost 10,000 people at the Roots Tech conference. Stairs, escalators and elevators are available. There is currently construction on one side which has the bathrooms closed on that side, however plenty of other available.

This is one of the biggest Conference Centers I've ever seen. You can literally walk for 20 minutes getting from one end to the other. There are a variety of rooms and spaces for holding events. Also, as a vendor, it's a fantastic facility for keeping clients comfortable. Quite often, convention centers can either be a little chilly or a little hot and stuffy when the rooms filled with people, but the temperature here was very comfortable throughout the entire building, which is a very big deal to me. An overall great experience.

I have been here before to attend conventions and loved the place. This year however, there was some construction going on and they had the bathrooms closest to the dinner hall closed. It was a good 5 minute walk each way to get to the bathrooms from dinner.

name: TRAX Light Rail System
reviews: This is a handy service to use when skiing in the Little Cottonwood Canyon. The ski resorts have partnered with the UTA, allowing your ski pass to have access to the bus and rail system. Easy to make a trip downtown and back

I should have researched taking the TRAX from SLC airport as it has a station only a block and a half away from my hotel.  Take it for FREE in the local area or pay only $2.50 to go to or from the airport!  Wonderful transit system.
Free if you are using downtown. It was easy to use, the timing seemed off, It is available late if needed. Double check on the time.
A $2.50 fare from the SLC airport to downtown is fantastic and fairly quick with not too many stops.

Since I had 24 hours between flights, I decided to visit downtown SLC on my own. TRAX was the perfect solution, and I took a direct train from the airport to Temple Square. The Rail System was clean and clearly marked. Seats were brightly designed, and there was adequate space for luggage and window gazing. Tickets were easily accessible, and there was a Senior discount. It was also handicapped equipped. Outdoor stations were well lit, and there were numerous panels describing the incoming and outgoing trains. I would highly recommend this inner city transportation system.

name: Eccles Theater
reviews: Salt Lake new performing arts theater is simply terrific.  The acoustics are perfect and the seating comfortable and nicely aligned to allow viewing of the stage.  Multiple levels of seating with boxes in the wings make for a first class experience.   We attended the touring company presentation of “Wicked” and it was Broadway quality.  The performance stage appears to have all of the special tools to allow flying monkeys to come to life and sound quality that rivals anything on Broadway.

What an amazing show! That cast was incredible! But this review is about the theater. What a beautiful facility. Very clean. I loved that the chairs were wide and you actually had leg room! It was nice to be able to purchase water and treats before the show. I was surprised that they actually sold alcohol at the Eccles. I was very impressed by the ushers and their helpfulness. Cant wait to see another show!

The inside ceiling resembles a starlit night sky. From the Lion King 2017, to Kurt Bestor's Christmas 2018 (Hamilton and others in between), this theater has created memorable experiences for my loved ones. Great gift ideas for graduation, birthdays, etc. All genres of shows. A wonderful contemporary addition to Salt Lake's existing theaters. Inside restaurant, water feature, adequate restrooms, and excellent professionally dressed (black and white) smiling staff. Close level parking is wonderful. Theater experience at its best!

We've been to quite a few shows at the Eccles. It's a great venue and hardly a bad seat in the house. Everyone we've ever interacted with there, from security to ushers to box office staff have been friendly and helpful. Seats are comfortable, the shows tend to start on time, and everything looks well maintained. Tickets tend to be spendy, but that's a reflection of the performers and not the venue itself, and they're actually cheaper than performances we've seen in other cities.

There's tons of parking nearby, curbside drop-off if you're taking an Über, and the Metro passes right by so getting there is no problem. There are tons of places to eat within just a few minutes' walking distance so you can eat before you catch your show.

Have only been to this theater once and find the seating is excellent and the performance, "Shen Gun", was also excellent, particularly the amazing sets. The theater is fairly new and the ushers and concessioniors were accomodating and helpful. The theater is easily accessible by  "TRAX".

My wife and I are now into our second season with Broadway Across America at the Eccles center. We live in Idaho but the travel during the winter is worth the entertainment at the Eccles. We love the shows included with the season ticket package and the fact that we get preferential treatment for other activities. We will keep this tradition going for many years in the future. We were able to buy enough tickets to Wicked to take all of our girls to the show. It made for a wonderful family weekend in SLC.

My husband and I have purchased season tickets for the Eccles Theater every season since they opened. We are delighted with most of the productions, and love sitting in the first row of the first tier. We have a perfect, unobstructed view of the stage, and the access in and out is very convenient. We always park directly across the street in the parking garage, and usually get free passes with our tickets. We also love that we can cancel a particular show and reschedule another. Best entertainment investment ever!

Last night was my first visit to the Eccles Theatre and I very much enjoyed it. Show was Wunderbar - Eddie Izzard - and so was the venue. Easy to get to, parking garage near and inexpensive, and just beautiful. One full wall in the lobby was a giant screen on which Utah’s beautiful scenery was on showcase in video. Whoever did the cinematography was brilliant! Lots of people took photos of it, and no wonder.

If you get a chance to catch a show here, take it! Big enough to share with lots of people but small enough that it felt very intimate.

name: Joseph Smith Memorial Building
reviews: The old Hotel Utah, now the Joseph Smith Memorial Building has a wonderfully beautiful lobby where you can sit and relax and at times enjoy light music.  There are many good restaurants in the building.
Tour the amazing beautiful building, watch a free movie on Jesus Christ, or eat at one of the amazing restaurants on the top floor with a view of Temple Square below.

The elegant lobby still reminds of  the building's halcyon days as the grand Hotel Utah, where famous visitors to Salt Lake City always stayed.  It is now officially a dedicated church facility,  home to  several church administrative departments.  However, the lobby and other areas of the building are open to the public. Its restaurants rooftop restaurants offer spectacular views overlooking Temple Square.  However, they no longer serve what was once reputed to be the best coffee in town.  As a rule, they serve good food that is moderately priced.

Once you come out of the elevators or simply walk in the Joseph Smith Bldg (formerly Hotel Utah)  you are greeted with elegance and grandure.

Take a tour, host a meeting or reception, and enjoy a fabulous dinner all with some of the greatest and best views in Utah.

When your done you can take a stroll around Temple Square, window shop at City Creek, and pay for underground cover parking.

Check for local events and schedules first, and revisit each season.

Enjoy.
I have been here several times over the years. I like the look.  Parking is an issue, but you can get comped at the restaurants.

This building is stunning. The artwork and details are breath taking. Everyone is welcomed. I recommend it to everyone even if you're not of the LDS religion. It can be a bit pricey if you're thinking of having a wedding here. When we had our's we spent quite a bit For such a small cermony. If you have the chance to eat at hte Roof I hightly recommend it! Beautiful view and amazing food.

The Joseph Smith memorial building, formerly known as the hotel Utah, is meant to impress and in all candor, it is impressive. Was built between 1909 and 1911 and used as a hotel until 1987. There are still three operational restaurants in the building. The manicured garden and pond in front of it on Temple Square are nice if you like a highly controlled landscape.
Wonderful building but why name it after a man who has never stepped foot in Salt Lake - let alone this building.   Just weird.  I wouldn't go again.

Our tour operator organised an evening meal in this fabulous restaurant. Situated on the top floor of this building, we had a beautiful view of the sun setting over Salt Lake. Food was buffet style with plenty of choice. Note that this is a church run facility and no alcohol is served. Would definitely go here again.

To reiterate the subject title, the Joseph Smith Memorial Building is an extravagant, luxurious, posh Building to behold; a treat for your visual senses. 

Indeed, the Joseph Smith Memorial Building is sublimely beautiful both in it elegant exterior design, as well as for its noble, high-class, epicurean interior decor, design, and amenities. We were told by its internal Guide that in its glorious, century-old past, it served as a hotel, and hosted USA Presidents, and assorted entertainment-industry celebrities. Today, the Joseph Smith Memorial Building is a public venue and lounge, and an "active museum" of sorts. 

When you visit the Joseph Smith Memorial Building, please make it a point to go to the top floor. You will thus be treated to sublime, uninterrupted views of the Temple Square, and of the Temple itself. The view is spell-binding; it will render you speechless and breathless. Moreover, the panoramic view of the top floor affords you the vista of the expansive downtown Salt Lake City core.

When you properly plan your itinerary -- and to mark any special personal occasion that you desire to bless with lush gallantry -- you may elect to dine at the top-floor "The Garden Restaurant."  You may dine at a window-side table that extends to you the aforementioned beautiful view of the Temple, Temple Square, and downtown Salt Lake City. The Garden Restaurant on the top floor of the Joseph Smith Memorial Building renders an experience at the Joseph Smith Memorial Building truly unique and special. 

The Joseph Smith Memorial Building is exclusively beautiful and calming, and most assuredly worthy of your time to visit, behold, dine, and experience.  

I will return to the Joseph Smith Memorial Building as my personal "go to" venue whenever I am in Salt Lake City to dine at The Garden Restaurant with my girlfriend to further treat her like a Princess, and to properly set the regal mood of my sojourn to Salt Lake City.

After breakfast in the Nauvoo, a cafe in the Joseph Smith Memorial Building, the volunteers gave good suggestions for activities. They explained the Giving Program - where you purchase an item in a vending machine and it is sent to a needy person. Additionally, with the  Christmas Holidays  they explained changes in the usual schedules in some buildings.  Local high school choirs were performing in various buildings in Temple Square area.  We thoroughly enjoyed the panoramic views from the 10th floor.  There are two upscale restaurants there too.  Then we arrived in time to watch a local High School Choir perform. They performed from the balcony which made it hard to both see and hear them. There are a variety videos available in the building.  Sorry our schedule didn't allow time to see some of them.

name: Land Cruiser Heritage Museum
address: 470 West 600 South, Salt Lake City, Utah
reviews: If you are a lover of the Toyota Land Cruiser or even if you just appreciate a beautiful collection of vintage vehicles this museum is an ABSOLUTE MUST!!!  An incredible collection of Land Cruisers dating back to 1953 through 2015.  You will find Land Cruisers from around the world, some utilitarian and some in beautiful mint condition.  There is also an extensive collection of Land Cruiser toys and models, as well as an awesome display of Land Cruiser pedal cars.  If you are visiting Salt Lake City or   a tourist in your own town, make sure you stop in for a visit - you will be wowed by the collection and knowledge of the curators!!

What can I say, loved this place. As a former Landcruiser owner it has been on my bucket list for a while. The folks working there were very friendly and informative, they know their stuff. There is every model of Landcruiser ever made here and also the first one brought to the States. I was in heaven. Highly recommend even to folks that have never owned one.

Just visited the land cruiser museum. It is an amazing collection and the staff are friendly and helpful. Great gift shop too!  This is a must visit spot for anyone with an interest in cruisers, so many unique vehicles.

Feeling a little nostalgic for my FJ40. There was a meticulous and beautiful example of it at the museum. Same color and year! Great collection of stock, custom, old and new Land Cruisers. I only wish you could see all of the vehicles for more angles. Space is at a premium, they have a lot of Land Cruisers on display... about a hundred!

I've owned a couple of Land Cruisers and thought I knew quite a bit about their history. Well, I surely know a lot more now. This museum offers fantastic exhibitions on Cruisers both domestic and foreign. These are historically significant vehicles and this museum helps you to understand why. It's not just for Cruiserheads but for anyone with an interest in automotive history. I can't wait for a return visit.
A must for any Cruiser Fan or 4x4 enthusiast!!! From the first model to the latest. Rigged out to stock.

We were amazed how many different models of landcruisers were produced across the world . All the vehicles are in incredible and original condition. Would highly recommend dropping in and having a look . We spoke with Dan who has a outstanding knowledge of the inventory.
TripAdvisor needs to be updated. I guess in the recent past the museum was free, but they do charge admission now as of October 2019.

name: Church History Museum
reviews:
The Family History Museum in Salt Lake City is an excellent collection of paintings, historical videos, and artifacts on the early history of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.  Newly opened is an exhibit called Suffragettes that focuses on Mormon women being the first to get the vote in the US but then how The Edmunds Tucker Act revoked their right and how they got it back.  Another exhibit just opening is entitled Temples Dot the Earth.  This is a very interactive exhibit designed for children, but informative for all ages.

Docents are scattered throughout the exhibit to answer questions, But you can choose how much time you want to spend exploring. Most people spend about 1.5 hours.

Free, open Mon - Fri 9:00am to 9:00 pm and Sat 10:00 am to 6:00 pm.  Closed Sunday.

Friendly atmosphere, lovely gift shop.

This is one of my absolute favorite sites in Utah. While I'm not a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, I would recommend this museum to any visitor to Salt Lake City as an opportunity to learn more about the religion that has played such a unique role in the city's founding and history. Because of my deep interest in Mormonism, I spent approximately five hours at this museum over two days, but since admission is free, your visit can be as long or as short as you want.

The first floor is focused on the history of the church in the 19th century. It's impressively curated, with one of the most memorable features being the 220-degree film of Joseph Smith's First Vision. However, I should note that some of the more controversial aspects of the Church's history are relatively glossed over in a way that may be unsatisfying to non-members. Little is said, for instance, about the practice of plural marriage, which is referred to in the exhibit as an "Abrahamic trial of faith."

The second floor will likely be of greater interest to members. The exhibit Presidents of the Church explores the lives of past prophets through personal artifacts and multi-media displays. There are also several halls of religious artwork.

Before leaving the museum, I'd definitely suggest a stop at the excellent gift shop, where I purchased a beautiful Salt Lake Temple ornament and greeting cards by Utah artist Brian Kershisnik.

This place is really nice in that they have quite a few original historical items here. Some of these items are just relics from pioneer days, but some have true historical significance. There are several first edition Books of Mormon and the original printing press from the first printing, I especially enjoyed the 180 degree film of Joseph Smith, and the exhibit on each of the prophets wherein they have various items from each of their lives, and focuses on their focus as prophet. They also have a really cool exhibit on the tabernacle organ. Very enjoyable, very interesting stuff, and very helpful docents. Also, I really like that they are complete and forthcoming about things whether they be flattering to the church or not.
We saw the great exhibition space devoted to the first voting women in the country in February--such a great opportunity to see how far we've come!
Oh my. Always something to see and do here. Great activities for the whole family. Wonderful church history exhibits.  Be sure to view the First Vision video and the exhibition of the Smith Family.

Great little museum to kill an hour in, learning all about the origins of the Church of the Latter Day Saints. I had almost no knowledge about Joseph Smith and the Mormons when I entered and in one hour was able to learn most of the significant details of this faith community including about its growth and existence in Utah. Also was able to ask several questions of the more-than-willing-to-help volunteers dotted around the museum. Well worth a visit even if you have no interest in joining the Mormon church.

The Family History Museum in Salt Lake City is an excellent collection of paintings, historical videos, and artifacts on the early history of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.  Newly opened is an exhibit called Suffragettes that focuses on Mormon women being the first to get the vote in the US but then how The Edmunds Tucker Act revoked their right and how they got it back.  Another exhibit just opening is entitled Temples Dot the Earth.  This is a very interactive exhibit designed for children, but informative for all ages.

Docents are scattered throughout the exhibit to answer questions, But you can choose how much time you want to spend exploring. Most people spend about 1.5 hours.

Free, open Mon - Fri 9:00am to 9:00 pm and Sat 10:00 am to 6:00 pm.  Closed Sunday.

Friendly atmosphere, lovely gift shop.

Wishing to have a clearer insight into the church of LDS, I spent a winter afternoon on the manicured grounds of the beautiful buildings within the walled Mormon area. Missionary Sisters offered a complimentary tour, and graciously spoke about the different areas and their significance. The North Visitor Center housed intricate artwork and furniture, plus a miniature recreation of the new earthquake proof building that will be built during the next 4 years. The Tabernacle contained the magnificent organ with the outrageous acoustics that are famous  worldwide. I especially enjoyed the Church History Museum, a two story building filled with numerous artifacts and remnants of the beginnings of the LDS Church. The journey begins with a wide open theatre film, and continues with the historical development of the Mormon movement. There are interactive displays and educational discussions. My favorite areas involved  the Suffrage Women Rights and their path to voting in Utah. There is an elevator, and a lovely gift shop.

name: Great Salt Lake State Park
reviews: You have got to visit the Great Salt Lake State Park. I cannot personally float in any body of water without a flotation device. I was amazed that I could float easily in the Great Salt Lake. It is an amazing experience. Showers are available within a couple hundred yards of the lake, invaluable for rinsing off the salt layer deposited upon your skin. Like the Nike slogan, Just Do It!

This park includes several paved campsites, a marina, visitor center, bathroom facilities and boat launch. I thoroughly enjoyed the incredible views overlooking GSL and learned a lot about the lake itself from the displays at the visitor center where the staff was very friendly. If one is looking to camp here, note there are just a small handful of sites (book far in advance). Day use and overnight fees apply. There is ample parking and several grassy and shaded areas feature picnic tables.

This place was so beautiful.  We saw antelope, bison, rabbits, and birds galore.  I am from the South and we simply don't have scenery like this.  There is a nature museum/ gift shop where you can learn more about the resident animals.  I went with a friend but will be back with my family!  There is a fair amount of walking and such to do if you choose, but most things are accessible by car.  They do have an eatery there, although we didn't visit it.

I love bringing visitors all the way out to the GSL.  The bison are amazing to watch, they are amazing animals.  It's usually also dry here if it's still snowy elsewhere as you get so much sun.  Nice hikes too.

This is a small State Park and Marina that let's you get close to the Great Salt Lake.  There is a small visitor center with a deck and viewing area or you can go down the path to the lake.  If you have a boat there is a marina.  It is worth a visit to learn about this area.

Was worth the drive out to see and learn about the Great Salt Lake. They have an informative short video and some displays in the Park Services building (modular) on site. When we were there, the ground around the lake was covered in krill and a little smelly, but it was cold enough to keep the smell down. Wear boots or shoes that can handle wet, if you want to walk along the lake.

My son and I took a trip to see Antelope Island and were not disappointed. The drive to the island itself is not that bad, but be prepared for a decent drive if you decided to explore the island. Once you get on the island it is several miles if you are willing to drive to the end of it. About halfway back, there are excellent opportunities for hiking IF you are in good shape. The vertical altitude change for those hikes is over 1000+ feet (if I'm not mistaken), but the view would've been well worth it. We were flat-landers and would've probably passed out before we completed the trek. But, the scenery is beautiful. I would definitely return to hike the trails IF is was in better shape!!!

For a few dollars you can drive and walk around the marina, see the tiny and kinda sad museum, and get some amazing views of the lake and some of its islands plus you can walk right down to the water and along the shore and rocks and salt deposits. I think the views and walking a few minutes to the water's edge and on the mud and brine and sand was totally worth the price of admission alone.
